The UV index is a measurement of the intensity of ultraviolet (UV) radiation from the sun. It is typically represented on a scale of 0 to 11 or higher, with higher numbers indicating higher levels of UV radiation. The UV index helps people understand the potential risks of sun exposure and guides them in taking appropriate sun protection measures, such as wearing sunscreen, protective clothing, and sunglasses, and seeking shade during peak UV hours.

Exposure to excessive UV radiation can pose several dangers to people. Here are some of the potential risks associated with prolonged or unprotected sun exposure: Sunburn: UV radiation can cause sunburn, which is characterized by red, painful, and inflamed skin. Severe sunburns can lead to blistering, peeling, and increased risk of skin damage. Skin Damage: Over time, repeated exposure to UV radiation can lead to premature aging of the skin, including wrinkles, fine lines, age spots, and sagging skin. It can also contribute to the development of skin cancer. Eye Damage: UV radiation can harm the eyes, causing conditions like photokeratitis (sunburn of the cornea) and cataracts (clouding of the eye\'s lens). Prolonged exposure to UV radiation without proper eye protection can increase the risk of these eye conditions. Suppression of Immune System: Excessive UV exposure can weaken the immune system, making individuals more susceptible to infections and diseases. Increased Risk of Skin Cancer: The most significant danger of UV radiation is its association with skin cancer. Prolonged and unprotected exposure to UV radiation, particularly intense sunburns during childhood, can increase the risk of developing skin cancer later in life. To minimize these risks, it is important to follow sun safety guidelines, such as wearing sunscreen, protective clothing, and sunglasses, seeking shade during peak UV hours, and avoiding excessive sun exposure.

Low Hazard: No sun protection required. A UV Index reading two or lower means there is a minimal risk of sunburn for the average person. At this level it is suggested to wear sunglasses, use broad spectrum sunscreen and watch out for bright surfaces like sand, water and snow which reflect UV rays, increasing your exposure. The time to burn can vary by skin type, but at a low UV level it is approximately 60 minutes.

UV Index reading between 3 and 5 means there is a moderate risk of sunburn for the average person. At this level it is suggested to seek shade between 10AM and 4PM when the sun’s rays are its strongest. Wearing protective clothing, including a hat and sunglasses, is a great way to limit exposure. Sunscreen should be applied every two hours, even on cloudy days, and reapplied after swimming or sweating. The time to burn can vary by skin type, but at a moderate UV level it is approximately 30 to 45 minutes.

UV Index reading 6 or 7 puts you at a high risk of harm from unprotected sun exposure. Following the steps from the moderate level is suggested. The time to burn can vary by skin type, but at a high UV level it is approximately 15 to 25 minutes.

UV Index reading 8 to 10 puts you at a very high risk of harm from unprotected sun exposure. Take extra precautions for both your skin and eyes because damage occurs quickly, typically within 15 minutes. Try to minimize your sun exposure during peak sun times, but if not possible then diligently apply and re-apply sunscreen and SPF lip balm.

A UV Index reading of 11 or higher places you at extreme risk of sunburn. Damage may occur in less than 10 minutes if unprotected. It is best to avoid all sun exposure between 10 AM and 4 PM at this level.
